results.title: Jazz in exile
results.creator_credit: Francerelli Film Productions and Chuck France
results.brief_description: Filmclips of American jazz performances and interviews with musicians are used to discuss why America has failed to appreciate its most prominent, indigenous art form. Why have so many artists left and settled in Europe and why have some gone home in the last few years? Musicians featured: Dexter Gordon, Johnny Griffin, Steve Lacy, Randy Weston, Phil Woods, Art Farmer, Richard Davis, Gato Barberie, Carla Bley, Freddie Hubbard, Mal Waldron.

results.title: Jazz greats: from Louis Armstrong to Duke Ellington (PC)
results.brief_description: SYSTEM REQUIREMENTS: 386-25 computer or better with 4MB of RAM, MPC CD-ROM player, S-VGA graphics card (640x480x256 colours) with compatible monitor, MPC compliant sound card, mouse, Windows 3.1. Using text, sound bytes and images, this CD ROM traces the history of jazz from Louis Armstrong to Duke Ellington. Chapters can be read on screen and cover big band jazz, jazz piano in the 1930s and 1940s, the New Orleans scene and women in jazz. A video gallery includes performances by Louis Armstrong in his first European tour, Duke Ellington and His Band performing “Sophisticated lady”, Count Basie and “I Left my baby” for the CBS TV broadcast of ‘The Sound of Jazz’ and Billie Holiday singing “Fine and mellow” at the same broadcast. There are discussions with jazz critic and historian Dr. Herb Wong as well as with musicians Dave Brubeck, Tee Carson and Shorty Rogers. Also included are the following songs as sound bytes: Jelly Roll Morton, “Black bottom stomp”; Louis Armstrong, “West end blues”; Coleman Hawkins, “Body and soul”; Duke Ellington, “Take the A train”; Johnny Hodges, “Jeep’s blues”; Bennie Goodman and Charlie Christian, “Breakfast feud”; Gene Krupa and Roy Eldridge, “Rockin’ chair”; Count Basie, “One o’clock jump”; Count Basie and Lester Young, “Lester leaps in”; James P. Johnson, “Carolina shout”; Fats Waller, “Aint misbehavin’”; Art Tatum, “Tea for two”; Bessie Smith, “Down hearted blues”; “Billie Holiday, “He’s funny that way”. The disk also contains a bibliography.

results.title: Javelin Throw
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Coaching and Training for Track and Field Events”.
Gives coaching tips for javelin throwing from Olympic athletes and coaches, plus footage of javelin events from the Moscow Olympics.

results.title: Javelin
results.creator_credit: Edmund Dorfmann and United World Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The United world track and field series”.

results.title: Japanese: language and people. [kit]
results.creator_credit: BBC, Intervoice Incorporated, Terry A. Doyle, Richard Smith, Trevor Hughes Parry and Brian Moeran
results.brief_description: This excellent kit comprising of five audio cassettes, a teacher manual and student reference book is designed to accompany the ‘Japanese: language and people’ videos. The tapes contain dialogues, exercises and practice material which is closely integrated to the course book. The teacher’s manual contains lesson suggestions in order to provide a strong framework for learning the language, while the course book provides an accessible introduction to the written language along with insights into contemporary Japanese society.
results.creator_credit_for_label: BBC, Intervoice Incorporated, Terry A. Doyle, Richard Smith, Trevor Hughes Parry and Brian Moeran

results.title: Japanese women [Short version]
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, John Taylor, Don Hopkins, George Johnson and Kalle Lasn
results.brief_description: A film that examines the changing roles and problems of women in Japan at a time in Japanese and Western societies when the nature of the family is undergoing rapid change and women’s role in society is being redefined.
results.creator_credit_for_label: ONF | NFB, John Taylor, Don Hopkins, George Johnson and Kalle Lasn

results.title: Japanese women
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, John Taylor, Don Hopkins and Kalle Lasn
results.brief_description: A film for those seeking insight into contemporary Japanese society, this one-hour documentary examines the status of women in Japan. Through a well-balanced blend of archival footage, candid interviews and fly-on-the-wall scenes of women at home and in the workplace, it investigates Japanese lifestyles, social values, labor practices and the women’s movement. A film highly recommended for students of Sociology and Far Eastern and Women’s Studies, as well as for those who intend to visit or do business with Japan. Related films: Japan Inc: Lessons for North America?
